Nigerian shares fell as much as 1.8 percent, their steepest drop since the beginning of the year, after the central bankâ€™s monetary policy team took an aggressive stance, raising the benchmark interest rate to 13 percent.

The move could add considerably to the pressure on stocks in the short term, as the promise of better returns could entice portfolio managers to sell large volumes of stocks and invest the profits in fixed-income instruments.
